Kanye West: An icon's gruesomely deteriorating image

21/11/2022

Alfie Sansom (he/him) comments on the swift rise and dramatic fall of hip-hop artist, Kanye West

Image by Kim Erlandsen, NRK P3

By Alfie Sansom

CONTENT WARNING: This article contains references to antisemitism and potentially upsetting themes.

The rockstar is discontinued. There will be no more Marc Bolans, no more Kurt Cobains. We have run out of Elvis Presleys, and Johnny Rottens, and Axl Roses. There are no more Ozzy Osbournes to bite a batâ€™s head off, nor Lennons to be killed, nor Gallaghers to feud. Whether it be the changing focus of the music industry for mass appeal, the lack of these bombastic personalities on offer, or the publicâ€™s unwillingness to stomach any more savagery â€“ what would Twitter say about a mammalâ€™s head being bitten off mid-performance â€“ there is no realistic demand for the rockstar to re-emerge. All we have now is an elusive Alex Turner and the mellow gruel of Chris Martin.

The pomp of the rockstar lies forever more in the gutter, wrinkled and shivering. However, from this pile of white ash, a new class of artistic rebel has risen â€“ the rapstar. Rap and hip-hop are second only to pop in terms of popularity, with half of the ten most streamed artists on Spotify being rappers (Drake, Bad Bunny, The Weeknd, Eminem, and Post Malone). A hedonistic, and at points violent, culture has emerged around this genre, from the aggressive gangsta rap of the late 80s/90s to the arrogant commercialisation of the 2000s â€˜bling eraâ€™, and the dampened sound of modern mumble rap. Combine this with the litany of critically acclaimed rappers â€“ Kendrick Lamar, Tyler the Creator, MF DOOM â€“, and the breeding ground for a rapstar is well and truly in the mainstream.

And no one couples controversy with critical acclaim quite like Kanye West. He is one of the greatest selling artists in history, and his achievements are not difficult to quantify: three Brits, 11 BPI Platinum album certifications, 24 Grammys, 160 RIAA Platinum single certifications, 250 million certified units sold and one Shoe of the Year Award. His contemporaries sing his praise, with musicians as varied as Drake, Adele and Arctic Monkeys naming West as an influence.

His albums are ground-breaking works of sonic force. His documentary, Jeen-Yuhs (2022), shows an ambitious and determined Kanye West struggling through the streets of Chicago and New York in search of a record deal. He started producing for other artists in 1996, with his breakthrough being in collaboration with Jay-Z, working on many tracks for The Blueprint (2001). It only took three years for his debut to release, The College Dropout (2004), peaking at number two on the US charts and earning him a Grammy, the first of many.

From there, it has been a chain of success. Since Westâ€™s debut, none of his albums have charted lower than number two in America, with the minimalistic 808s and Heartbreak, industrial Yeezus and gospel-driven JESUS IS KING keeping him at the forefront of popular culture. He has worked with some of the biggest names in music, collaborating with Katy Perry, Rihanna and Lil Nas X, always able to wring out a hit. Fashion has been a successful venture for the rapper, his Yeezy shoes becoming an iconic item, bringing him deals with Adidas, the GAP and Balenciaga.

His controversies are equally as emphatic. West has disrupted three award shows (2004, 2006, 2009), the most infamous of which being the latter, where he snatched the microphone form the award-winner, Taylor Swift, to denounce her win and declare his support for Beyonce. From here, he claimed to have made Swift â€œfamousâ€, in his song aptly named â€˜Famousâ€™, leading to a tirade of abuse from fans against Swift. He also interrupted a charity broadcast for those affected by Hurricane Katrina, with the immortal words â€œGeorge Bush doesnâ€™t care about black peopleâ€. The accused claims it was â€œone of the most disgusting momentsâ€ of his presidency. Even Barack Obama called him a â€œjackassâ€. Scathing.

Most controversies stem from Westâ€™s over-confident verbiage. Sometimes he compares himself to Willy Wonka, or Michelangelo; sometimes he says that slavery â€œsounds like a choiceâ€, and that he is just trying to present â€œnew ideasâ€. He claims to be a trailblazing freethinker, and with such outrageous claims, it should be considered worrying how freely he is thinking.

But surely these are the actions of a diva, a rapstar, and not a properly problematic character? However, recently, his public comments and â€˜endeavoursâ€™ have been getting worse. His rapturous support of Donald Trump, as well as the â€˜White Lives Matterâ€™ ideology, has garnered much criticism, although West claims it to be an attempt at unity, stating that â€œwearinâ€™ the hatâ€™ll show the people that we equalâ€ (Ye Vs The Peopleâ€™). However, West has now been locked out of his Instagram and Twitter accounts for hateful remarks about Judaism, threatening to go â€œdeath [sic] con 3 ON JEWISH PEOPLEâ€. Clearly, his definition of â€˜equalâ€™ is warped.

In fact, this antisemitism can be seen as early as 2013. He claimed in a radio interview that â€œblack people donâ€™t have the same level of connections as Jewish peopleâ€, attempting to perpetuate the age-old myth of an Illuminati-esque control by all Jewish people. When looking back on the comment, he suggested he was trying to give a â€œcomplimentâ€, saying that he doesnâ€™t know â€œhow being told you have money is an insultâ€.

Furthermore, a known associate of Kanye West has been reportedly handing out â€˜White Lives Matterâ€™ t-shirts on Skid Row. This is a famously impoverished neighbourhood in Los Angeles, with a predominantly homeless population and a majorly black/African American demographic. The combination of the struggling minority group and the oppressive hate-speech emblazoned t-shirts does not seem the most considered act of charity possible.

Nor has he backed down. Kanye West has agreed to buy the American conservative-backed social media service, Parler. This platform has been removed by Apple and Google, after the 6 January Storming of the U.S. Capitol was partly orchestrated using their app. Kanye is seemingly fleeing to a site better suited for his views to reside.

Can we truly blame Kanye West for his comments? He was diagnosed with bipolar disorder in 2016, and although he often denies the legitimacy of thus diagnosis, many fans say this is just another manic episode, and that he will wake up one day, realising the damage he has done to his own brand, and relent. This blame cannot be solely placed on Westâ€™s mental health, however. While previous outbursts have led to celebrity gossip and infighting, his recent ventures have caused real damage to people. Where are his friends, his family, his managers, and his colleagues, who should be trying to prevent this?

So, what should the proper reaction be? Shock and disgust, of course, but amongst these emotions, should any action be taken? People often call for the perpetrator to be sacked, and West has already been abandoned by his brand partners, including Adidas, and removed from social media platforms, although he still has enough wealth to buy ownership of his own service. Whether greater measures will be taken is yet to be seen; Kanye West has already received international condemnation for his conduct.

But on a personal level, can any meaningful action be taken? Considering the high sales of every Kanye West album, he certainly has some level of fanbase, and it is arguably a harsh task for them to forsake his whole discography. And yet West will still profit from these listens, every stream another penny into his pockets. He will continue to make music, to chart with each album, to earn certifications and to win awards. Or will he?

Kanye Westâ€™s image is most certainly a fast-melting candle. His spark of genius (as he so often likes to call himself) has released the sweet scent of 14 studio albums, an aroma worthy of almost every award available to a musician. But the wax is shrinking too quickly, the flame unruly and biting. To call it irredeemable is an unforgiving opinion, but the self-cannibalism of Westâ€™s public identity, disfigured through this series of hateful comments and controversial acts, is too fierce for a slow-down to seem likely. For many, it is upsetting to see their icon, their hero, become so hated; even more devastating for an accomplished collection of art to become damaged by proximity with its creator. Perhaps West will have a change of heart, or at least fire his publicist. In the meantime, if one must listen to his music, as Iâ€™m sure many will continue to do, it may be worthwhile to remember the artist, who can create such discographies but simultaneously hold his views, and consider the impact his actions can have on whole groups of people.
